conversation.content: You said you'd teach me. Three months ago, you promised.

I know, I know—life got complicated. But we're here now, aren't we? The telescope's all set up, Jupiter's perfectly positioned, and I even brought those expensive filters you wouldn't stop talking about.
It's two in the morning.

Best time for viewing! Light pollution's at its lowest, atmospheric distortion minimal. Plus, there's something magical about the world when everyone else is asleep—like the universe is putting on a private show just for us.
You disappeared for three months, Marcus. Not a text, not a call.

[very quickly] The research grant fell through, Dad had his second stroke, Elena left—everything hit at once. I couldn't drag you into that mess, couldn't be the person who dims your light when mine was barely flickering.
I would've helped.
That's exactly why I couldn't tell you. You fix things, it's what you do. But some things need to break completely before they can be rebuilt properly.
Is that what you did? Break completely?
[monotone] More or less. Spent two weeks eating nothing but instant noodles. Rock bottom has terrible cuisine.
[trailing off] I kept checking the obituaries...

[very excited] Wait, seriously? That's morbid! Though I suppose if I was going to make the news, it would've been for stealing that radio telescope from Caltech—which, for the record, was borrowing with aggressive intentions to return.
You stole from Caltech?
Borrowed! They have seventeen of them, and mine was collecting dust in storage. Besides, I made a breakthrough—found evidence of those gravitational anomalies we theorized about sophomore year.
[chuckle] Of course you did. While having a breakdown.
Best discoveries happen at the edges of sanity. Galileo, Tesla, that guy who invented Post-It notes—all their greatest moments came from beautiful disasters.
Post-It notes were an accident, not a breakdown.
Exactly my point! Failure and discovery are dance partners. Speaking of which, look through the eyepiece—Jupiter's Great Red Spot should be rotating into view right about now.
[very quietly] I thought you were dead, Marcus.
Not dead, just... recalibrating. Like when you adjust a telescope's mirrors—sometimes you have to take the whole thing apart to see clearly again. But I'm here now, and the universe is waiting.
